Author: SemicolonButterfly
Text: It sounds like you really care about him <3 For me, it’s important to remember that while it’s good to be aware of how we’re impacting others...everyone is also on their own journey. Whatever his journey is with disordered eating, it is not your fault. That is not a burden you have to carry <3 Sadly, it’s a fairly frequent experience for someone to start pursing healthy changes, and then to cross some invisible line into disordered eating behavior that can take on a life of it’s own. Have you tried expressing your concern to him? I’m not that great at talking about the real stuff with people but the “I feel ( ) when ( ) because ( )” format from therapy has been helpful to me. Which is some of what I hear you saying in your post actually. That you feel worried when you see him engaging in certain behaviors because you want him to be around and healthy for a long time. Maybe that could be a place to start? I can relate to having intense worrying about whether I’ve hurt someone and it spiraling into a very dark brain space, so I hope some light finds its way in today.
